index.html
XGR+ User Manual Section 1 OVERVIEW

XGR+ User Manual 2023-03-08 Section 1 OVERVIEW FIGURE 1.1: The logo for eXploring Genomic Relations + (XGR PLUS). Motivation We are pleased to introduce an updated version of our XGR software, which has gained increasing popularity in genomics research since its first release (see Genome Medicine 2016). This update features a newly designed web server, called XGR Plus or XGR+, now made available here to all users for free and without any login requirements. It enables almost real-time enrichment and subnetwork analyses for a user-input list of genes, SNPs, genomic regions, or protein domains, leveraging ontologies, networks, and many other knowledgebase resources, such as functional genomic datasets about e/pQTL, promoter capture Hi-C, and enhancer-gene maps. Besides, the web server is user-friendly, very suitable for users who are unfamiliar with coding. One of the major challenges in genomics research is how to bridge the gap between generated genomic summary data and downstream knowledge discovery. We define genomic summary data as a list of genes or SNPs (more generally, genomic regions), along with their significance levels (e.g. p-values). We are leading the field in making sense of genomic summary data for knowledge discovery through developing approaches and tools that have been verified to be efficient and effective, including XGR (see Genome Medicine 2016), dnet (see Genome Medicine 2014), Priority index (see Nature Genetics 2019), and dcGO (see Nucleic Acids Research 2013). Building upon our previous approaches that have stood the test of time (with most of citations received in the past two years), and also incorporating the growing knowledgebase of ontologies and networks, XGR+ offers seven analysers for enrichment and subnetwork analyses, each doing specific interpretations tailored to genomic summary data at the gene, SNP, genomic region, and protein domain levels. Enrichment Analysers ENRICHMENT ANALYSER (GENES) - EAG, identifies ontology terms enriched for input genes; see Example Output ENRICHMENT ANALYSER (SNPS) - EAS, identifies ontology terms enriched for genes linked from input SNPs; see Example Output ENRICHMENT ANALYSER (REGIONS) - EAR, identifies ontology terms enriched for genes linked from input genomic regions; see Example Output ENRICHMENT ANALYSER (DOMAINS) - EAD, identifies ontology terms enriched for input protein domains; see Example Output Subnetwork Analysers SUBNETWORK ANALYSER (GENES) - SAG, identifies a gene subnetwork based on input gene-level summary data; see Example Output SUBNETWORK ANALYSER (SNPS) - SAS, identifies a gene subnetwork based on genes linked from input SNP-level summary data; see Example Output SUBNETWORK ANALYSER (REGIONS) - SAR, identifies a gene subnetwork based on genes linked from input genomic region-level summary data; see Example Output

mobile-first-webserver.html
Section 3 MOBILE-FIRST WEBSERVER

Section 3 MOBILE-FIRST WEBSERVER The XGR+ is designed as a mobile-first and responsive webserver (frontend). It is backed by a real-time Perl web framework (backend) that facilitates nearly zero-effort interface updates and maintenance. FIGURE 3.1: The screenshots for the XGR+ visited using Google Chrome in iPhone. Left: the frontpage; Right: the help page.
compatibility-runtime.html
Section 4 COMPATIBILITY & RUNTIME

Section 4 COMPATIBILITY & RUNTIME TABLE 4.1: A summary of the XGR+ browser compatibility. MacOS (Big Sur) Windows (10) Linux (Ubuntu) Safari 15.6.1 N/A N/A Edge N/A 108.0.1462.54 N/A Chrome 108.0.5359.124 108.0.5359.124 108.0.5359.124 Firefox 108.0.1 108.0.1 108.0.1 TABLE 4.2: A summary of the runtime (computed on the server side) per analyser. Analysers Description Runtime EAG ENRICHMENT ANALYSER (GENES) ~9 seconds EAS ENRICHMENT ANALYSER (SNPS) ~55 seconds EAR ENRICHMENT ANALYSER (REGIONS) ~20 seconds EAD ENRICHMENT ANALYSER (DOMAINS) ~2 seconds SAG SUBNETWORK ANALYSER (GENES) ~47 seconds SAS SUBNETWORK ANALYSER (SNPS) ~55 seconds SAR SUBNETWORK ANALYSER (REGIONS) ~23 seconds
help-buttons.html
Section 5 HELP BUTTONS

Section 5 HELP BUTTONS Each user-request interface features a toggle button labelled Show/Hide Info. This button contains information on how to use the interface, including details on input, output, and other relevant information. Additionally, there is an Example I/O button that showcases example inputs and outputs. For example, the screenshot below displays the Show/Hide Info toggle button in the SUBNETWORK ANALYSER (REGIONS) interface. FIGURE 5.1: The screenshots for the Show/Hide Info toggle button in the SUBNETWORK ANALYSER (REGIONS) interface.
error-messages.html
Section 6 ERROR MESSAGES

Section 6 ERROR MESSAGES The error messages will be displayed, for example, if the input data into the SUBNETWORK ANALYSER (REGIONS) is invalid (see the screenshot below). Notably, in the results page, a summary of input data is also returned to the users for reference. FIGURE 6.1: The screenshot for the error messages shown when the input is invalid, taking as example, the SUBNETWORK ANALYSER (REGIONS) interface.
enrichment-analyser-genes---eag.html
Section 7 ENRICHMENT ANALYSER (GENES) - EAG 7.1 Input Interface 7.2 Enrichment Results

Section 7 ENRICHMENT ANALYSER (GENES) - EAG 7.1 Input Interface Input Step 1: Enter a list of genes. Please ensure that the input gene identifiers are official symbols; otherwise, the error messages will be prompted. Step 2: Select from a list of supported ontologies. More Controls: Use additional parameters to fine-tune the above steps. SUBMIT: click the SUBMIT button to execute the analysis. Output Example Output includes interactive tables and high-quality figures for enrichment results. A summary of input data and the server-side computation runtime is also returned for reference. FIGURE 7.1: The interface of ENRICHMENT ANALYSER (GENES) - EAG, including the Show/Hide Info toggle button that contains the help information on inputs, outputs, and other information. 7.2 Enrichment Results Under the Input gene information tab, An interactive table displays the user-input gene list. FIGURE 7.2: The user-input data displayed under the Input gene information tab returned for exploration. Under the Output: enriched terms tab, An interactive table lists enriched ontology terms. FIGURE 7.3: An interactive table listing enriched ontology terms under the Output: enriched terms tab. Under the Output: forest plot tab, A forest plot illustrates enriched ontology terms. The downloadable pdf file is also provided. FIGURE 7.4: A forest plot for enriched ontology terms. Under the tab Output: dotplot, An dotplot illustrates enriched ontology terms. The downloadable pdf file is also provided. FIGURE 7.5: A dotplot for enriched ontology terms.
enrichment-analyser-snps---eas.html
Section 8 ENRICHMENT ANALYSER (SNPS) - EAS 8.1 Input Interface 8.2 Enrichment Results

Section 8 ENRICHMENT ANALYSER (SNPS) - EAS 8.1 Input Interface Input Step 1: Enter a list of SNPs, where the 1st column contains dbSNP rsIDs and the 2nd column for the significance information (p-values ranging between 0 and 1). Step 2: Specify the population to include SNPs in linkage disequilibrium. By default, input SNPs with p-values < 5e−8 are considered, and additional SNPs in linkage disequilibrium (R2 >= 0.8) can be included according to the specified population. Step 3: Use genomic proximity, quantitative trait locus mapping, or promoter capture Hi-C to identify linked genes. Step 4: Select from a list of supported ontologies. More Controls: Use additional parameters to fine-tune the steps described above. SUBMIT: click the SUBMIT button to execute the analysis. Output Example Output includes interactive tables and high-quality figures for enrichment results. A summary of input data and the runtime (computed on the server side) is also returned for reference. FIGURE 8.1: The interface of ENRICHMENT ANALYSER (SNPS) - EAS. The Show/Hide Info toggle button contains the help information on inputs, outputs, and other information. 8.2 Enrichment Results Under the Input SNP information tab, An interactive table lists the user-input SNPs. FIGURE 8.2: The user-input data under the Input SNP information tab returned for exploration. Under the Output: linked genes tab, An interactive table lists genes linked from the input SNPs. FIGURE 8.3: An interactive table listing genes linked from the input SNPs under the Output: linked genes tab. Under the Output: enriched terms tab, An interactive table lists enriched ontology terms. FIGURE 8.4: An interactive table lists enriched ontology terms under the Output: enriched terms tab. Under the Output: forest plot tab, A forest plot illustrates enriched ontology terms. A downloadable pdf file is also provided. FIGURE 8.5: A forest plot for enriched ontology terms under the Output: forest plot tab. Under the Output: dotplot tab, A dotplot illustrates enriched ontology terms. A downloadable pdf file is also provided. FIGURE 8.6: A dotplot for enriched ontology terms under the Output: dotplot tab.

Section 9 ENRICHMENT ANALYSER (REGIONS) - EAR 9.1 Input Interface Input Step 1 and Step 2: Enter a list of genomic regions. Please ensure that input genomic coordinates (Step 2) are consistent with the genome build (Step 1) Step 3: Use genomic proximity, quantitative trait locus mapping, or promoter capture Hi-C to identify linked genes. Step 4: Select from a list of supported ontologies. More Controls: Use additional parameters to fine-tune the steps described above. SUBMIT: click the SUBMIT button to execute the analysis. Section 10 ENRICHMENT ANALYSER (DOMAINS) - EAD 10.1 Input Interface 10.2 Enrichment Results

Section 10 ENRICHMENT ANALYSER (DOMAINS) - EAD 10.1 Input Interface Input Step 1 and Step 2: Enter a list of protein domains and specify their domain type. It is important to ensure that the input domain identifiers (Step 2) are consistent with the specified domain level (Step 1); otherwise, the error messages will be prompted. Step 3: Select from a list of supported ontologies. More Controls: Use additional parameters to fine-tune the steps described above. SUBMIT: click the SUBMIT button to execute the analysis. Output Example Output includes interactive tables and high-quality figures for enrichment results. A summary of input data and the runtime, which is computed on the server side, is also provided for reference. FIGURE 10.1: The interface of ENRICHMENT ANALYSER (DOMAINS) - EAD. The Show/Hide Info toggle button contains the help information on how to use it, including inputs, outputs, and other relevant information. 10.2 Enrichment Results Under the Input domain information tab, An interactive table lists the user-input domains. FIGURE 10.2: The user-input data under the Input domain information tab, which is available for exploration. Under the Output: enriched terms tab, An interactive table lists enriched ontology terms. A downloadable pdf file is also available. FIGURE 10.4: A forest plot for enriched ontology terms. Under the Output: dotplot tab, A dotplot illustrates enriched ontology terms. A downloadable pdf file is also available. FIGURE 10.5: A dotplot for enriched ontology terms.
subnetwork-analyser-genes---sag.html
Section 11 SUBNETWORK ANALYSER (GENES) - SAG 11.1 Input Interface 11.2 Subnetwork Results

Section 11 SUBNETWORK ANALYSER (GENES) - SAG 11.1 Input Interface Input Step 1: Enter a list of genes, with the 1st column for gene symbols and the 2nd column for the significance info (p-values between 0 and 1). Step 2 and Step 3: Identify a subnetwork of highly-scored genes from a gene network (Step 2), with the desired number of genes in the resulting subnetwork (Step 3). The significance (p-value) of observing the identified subnetwork by chance can also be estimated by a degree-preserving node permutation test. More Controls: Use additional parameters to fine-tune the steps described above. SUBMIT: click the SUBMIT button to execute the analysis. Output Example Output includes interactive tables and high-quality figures for the resulting subnetwork. A summary of input data and the runtime (computed on the server side) is also provided for reference. FIGURE 11.1: The interface of SUBNETWORK ANALYSER (GENES) - SAG. The Show/Hide Info toggle button contains the help information on how to use it, including inputs, outputs, and other relevant information. 11.2 Subnetwork Results Under the Input gene-level summary data tab, An interactive table lists user-input summary data. FIGURE 11.2: The user-input summary under the Input gene-level summary data tab returned for exploration. Under the Output: subnetwork tab, A network visualisation of the subnetwork is provided, along with An interactive table for the subnetwork genes. FIGURE 11.3: Visualisation of the identified subnetwork, with genes/nodes color-coded by input gene significance information under the Output: subnetwork tab.
subnetwork-analyser-snps---sas.html
Section 12 SUBNETWORK ANALYSER (SNPS) - SAS 12.1 Input Interface 12.2 Subnetwork Results

Section 12 SUBNETWORK ANALYSER (SNPS) - SAS 12.1 Input Interface Input Step 1: Input a list of SNPs with dbSNP rsIDs in the first column and corresponding significance information (p-values between 0 and 1) in the second column. Step 2: Specify the population to include SNPs in linkage disequilibrium. By default, input SNPs with p-values < 5e−8 are considered. Additional SNPs in linkage disequilibrium (R2 >= 0.8) can also be included according to the specified population. Step 3: Use genomic proximity, quantitative trait locus mapping, or promoter capture Hi-C to identify linked genes. Step 4 and Step 5: A subnetwork of highly-scored genes is identified from a gene network (Step 4), with the desired number of genes in the resulting subnetwork (Step 5). The significance (p-value) of observing the identified subnetwork by chance can also be estimated by a degree-preserving node permutation test. More Controls: Use additional parameters to fine-tune the steps described above. SUBMIT: click the SUBMIT button to execute the analysis. Output Example Output includes interactive tables and high-quality figures for the resulting subnetwork. A summary of input data and the runtime (computed on the server side) is also returned for reference. FIGURE 12.1: The interface of SUBNETWORK ANALYSER (SNPS) - SAS. The Show/Hide Info toggle button contains instructions on how to use the interface, including inputs, outputs, and other relevant information. 12.2 Subnetwork Results Under the Input SNP information tab, An interactive table displays user-input summary data. FIGURE 12.2: An interactive table displaying user-input summary under the Input SNP information tab returned for exploration. Under the tab Output: linked genes, An interactive table lists genes linked from the input SNPs. FIGURE 12.3: An interactive table listing genes linked from input SNPs under the Output: linked genes tab. Under the Output: subnetwork tab, A network visualisation of the subnetwork is provided, along with An interactive table for the subnetwork genes. FIGURE 12.4: A network visualisation of the resulting subnetwork, with genes/nodes color-coded by linked gene scores (ranged from 1 to 10) under the Output: subnetwork tab.
subnetwork-analyser-regions---sar.html
Section 13 SUBNETWORK ANALYSER (REGIONS) - SAR 13.1 Input Interface 13.2 Subnetwork Results

Section 13 SUBNETWORK ANALYSER (REGIONS) - SAR 13.1 Input Interface Input Step 1 and Step 2: Input a list of genomic regions with two columns. The 1st column contains genomic regions in the format of chr:start-end, and the 2nd column for the significance information (p-values between 0 and 1). Step 3: Use genomic proximity, enhancer-gene maps, or promoter capture Hi-C to identify linked genes. Step 4 and Step 5: A subnetwork of highly-scored genes is identified from a gene network (Step 4), with the desired number of genes in the resulting subnetwork (Step 5). The significance (p-value) of observing the identified subnetwork by chance can also be estimated by a degree-preserving node permutation test. More Controls: Use additional parameters to fine-tune the steps described above. SUBMIT: click the SUBMIT button to execute the analysis. Output Example Output includes interactive tables and high-quality figures for the resulting subnetwork. A summary of input data and the runtime (computed on the server side) is also provided for reference. FIGURE 13.1: The interface of SUBNETWORK ANALYSER (REGIONS) - SAG, including the Show/Hide Info toggle button with the help information on how to use the interface. 13.2 Subnetwork Results Under the Input genomic region information tab, An interactive table lists user-input summary data. FIGURE 13.2: User-input summary data under the Input genomic regions information tab returned for exploration. Under the Output: linked genes tab, An interactive table lists genes linked from the input genomic regions. FIGURE 13.3: An interactive table listing genes linked from the input genomic regions under the Output: linked genes tab. Under the Output: subnetwork tab, A network visualisation of the identified subnetwork is provided, along with An interactive table for the subnetwork genes. FIGURE 13.4: A network visualisation of the resulting subnetwork under the Output: subnetwork tab, with genes/nodes color-coded by linked gene scores, which range from 1 to 10.
